Jim Gilbert wrote:

> Rich,
> Piec=
es like that seem to have been used to change the shape of the 
> seppa dai=
 to accommodate a certain shape and/or size of saya and 
> tsuka.  There ar=
e tsuba where the seppa dai has been enlarged by 
> fitting pieces all of t=
he way around.  Sometimes various pieces 
> (including the more common hits=
uana plugs) are inserted by a later 
> collector to restore the look of the=
 guard to something like what he 
> believes to be its original state.
>
> =
I could imagine a piece like being inserted to repair damage if it 
> were =
somewhere else on the guard.  It's hard to imagine how that 
> particular s=
pot would be damaged. 
>
> I have seen a fair number of tsuba that have a p=
ronounced asymmetry to 
> the shape of the seppa dai in that location.  The=
re is metal "missing" 
> from the same position at the upper right.  My gue=
ss is that at some 
> time and/or place a slightly asymmetrical tsuka or sa=
ya shape was in 
> style and that tsuba were either made or modified to acc=
ommodate that 
> shape.  I haven't come across such a koshirae and not bein=
g a sword 
> user I can't guess as to why such a shape might be desirable. =

>
> The insert on your guard might be an attempt to change one of these 
>=
 tsuba to the more common symmetrical oval shape.
>
> Any other ideas?
>
> =
Jim
